Former Will Act As Chairman Of New Body; Will
Take Control On July 1
John S. MacGill, Jerome S. Bloom
and W. E. Holt Maulsby will be the
members of next year's Student Activities Committee, it was announced
today by President Joseph S. Ames.
MacGill, who was the junior representative on this year's committee,
will serve as chairman of the body.
Bloom will be the senior representative on the body and will act as
secretary, while Maulsby will be the
junior representative. The new appointees will work along with the
present committee and will take complete control on July 1.
Abrams Comments
In speaking of the new appointments, Robert C. Abrams, retiring
chairman, said, "I am very highy
pleased with the new men. The new
chairman, John MacGill, has done
very good work and certainly deserves
the appointment. The choice of Bloom
seems very fortunate as he will have
ample time to devote to the body.
Maulsby also appears capable of assuming the responsibility of such an
appointment.
"The Student Activities Committee
has passed the experimental stage
and I believe the new members will
make further progress," continued
Abrams.
Active On Campus
The three new men are very active
on the campus. MacGill is a member of 0. D. K. He is next year's
manager of football and holds the
backstroke record on the swimming
team. He is also a member of the
Barnstormer Club. He is a student
in the School of Business Economics.
Bloom is an honor student in the
School of Business Economics and is
serving on the Junior Prom Committee. Maulsby is also a student in the
School of Business Economics. He is
a member of the Musical Club and
was elected vice-president of the
Sophomore Class.

An illustrated booklet entitled
Undergraduate Schools, and portraying various views of the University has been released by the
registrar's office.
The brochure contains pictures
of the campus, including views of
the gymnasium drives, Levering
Hall, and informal snapshots taken
in classrooms and offices.
Prints taken from the booklet
may be purchased at the Alumni
Office in Remsen Hall.

a call was issued to the University

the Barnstormers' next production,
Road to Rome, a play in three acts
by Robert Emmett Sherwood.

rally, which was addressed by the

and Howard Caplan, and the organization's president, Zena.s Sears. Rehearsals were called for every night
this week. As the play is scheduled
for presentation on the evening of
May 11 the cast is expected to be
chosen in the near future.

at the Belasco Theatre in Washington
in 1927 and was seen by many during its long season run, as a big comedy hit, at the Playhouse in New
York. At these presentations, the
leading roles of Amytis, Hannibal and
Mago were acted by Jane Cowl, Philip Merivale and Barry Jones, respectively, all of whom are well known
headliners in the theatrical world.
The coaches invite everyone to try
out for the play, especially because
of the greater number of people to
be chosen. The cast requires twentytwo male parts to be filled, giving
more students than ever an opportunity to demonstrate their dramatic
ability and perhaps to fulfill their ambitions.

The names of fourteen recipients
of scholarships and fellowships for
the coming year from the Johns Hopkins University were announced Saturday by President Ames.
The Adam T. Bruce Fellowship in
biology was awarded to Joseph F. Oliphant, the George Peabody Scholarship was awarded to Charles Cramer,
Dr. John B. Davis received the William H. Grafflin Scholarship for advanced study in industrial chemistry,
Abraham Sachs was granted the William S. Rayner Fellowship for the
promotion of Semitic studies and
William G. Fletcher received tlie Edmund L. Royers Fellowship.
The Basil L. Gildersleeve Fellowship in Greek went to William K.
Pritchett, The Henry E. Johnston, Jr.,
Scholarship in biology to Tze Tuan
Chen, the James Buchanan Johnston
Scholarship in botany to Dr. George
Papenfuss and the Henry E. Johnston Schothrship in philosophy to Leo
Abraham.
The Johnston Scholarships are
awarded to students who have obtained their doctorate. The holders are
permitted to spend part of the year
away from the University, the only
stipulation on their research being
that they must not teach elsewhere.
Cedric S. Voulter received the
Charles A. W. Vogler Memorial Archaeological Fund in Greek Archaeology. This student also is permitted
to study abroad.
The one scholarship open to women
students only, the Cornelia G. Harcum Scholarship in Classical Archaeology was given for the second time
to Miss Eleanor Lay.
The Edward Franklin Buchner Research Fund in education was awarded to Miss Beulah Benton.
All of the present appointments
have been in the School of Higher
Studies.

Garvan Fellow Named
Robert Henry Krieble of Haverford
College has been chosen as the successful candidate for the Mary Carroll Garvan Fellowship for Connecticut. Mr. Francis P. Garvan gives this
fellowship in memory of his mother,
Mary Carroll Garvan. The annual stipend of $1,000 is paid to the holder
for a period of four years, contingent
upon the satisfactory progress of the
student. Mr. Krieble will work for his
doctorate degree at the Johns Hopkins University.

John S. MacGill, Jerome S. Bloom
and W. E. Holt Maulsby will be the
members of next year's Student Activities Committee, it was announced
today by President Joseph S. Ames.
MacGill, who was the junior representative on this year's committee,
will serve as chairman of the body.
Bloom will be the senior representative on the body and will act as
secretary, while Maulsby will be the
junior representative. The new appointees will work along with the
present committee and will take complete control on July 1.
Abrams Comments
In speaking of the new appointments, Robert C. Abrams, retiring
chairman, said, "I am very highy
pleased with the new men. The new
chairman, John MacGill, has done
very good work and certainly deserves
the appointment. The choice of Bloom
seems very fortunate as he will have
ample time to devote to the body.
Maulsby also appears capable of assuming the responsibility of such an
appointment.
"The Student Activities Committee
has passed the experimental stage
and I believe the new members will
make further progress," continued
Abrams.

on the campus. MacGill is a member of 0. D. K. He is next year's
manager of football and holds the
backstroke record on the swimming
team. He is also a member of the
Barnstormer Club. He is a student
in the School of Business Economics.
Bloom is an honor student in the
School of Business Economics and is
serving on the Junior Prom Committee. Maulsby is also a student in the
School of Business Economics. He is
a member of the Musical Club and
was elected vice-president of the
Sophomore Class.

Under the leadership of Reuben
Baer, a member of the athletic staff,
and Lawrence Gardiner, a student, a
badminton league under the sponsorship of the Playground Athletic
League is in the process of formation.
The league will consist of a seventeam circuit including both faculty
and undergraduate teams of the Hopkins and teams representing the St.
George A. C., the Y. M. C. A., the
First Presbyterian Church, and Mt.
Washington.
A team entrance fee of four dollars will be charged to take care of
lighting, heating, and other necessary
expenses.
The league will have at its disposal two courts in the Hopkins gymnasium, where the league games will
be played every Tuesday and Thursday next. A match will consist of
one single and two double games. Individual awards will be given to winners of the league.
